Problem:
We consider a quantum system where the wave function \\( \\psi(x, t) \\) evolves according to the Schrödinger equation with a potential function \\( V(x) \\). We study the effect of a measurement operator \\( M \\) applied at time \\( t_1 \\) defined as \\( M \\psi(x, t_1) = e^{-iH\\tau}\\psi(x, t_1) \\) where \\( H \\) is the Hamiltonian of the system and \\( \\tau \\) is a measurement time interval.

Given a final observed state \\( \\psi(x, T) \\) at time \\( T \\), can we determine precisely whether the measurement operator \\( M \\) was applied at \\( t_1 \\) without additional information?
Explanation: Without additional context or data on system conditions at or around \\( t_1 \\), it is generally impossible to back-calculate accurately whether \\( M \\) was applied due to the inherent uncertainty and variability in quantum state evolution and superposition.
